TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

TunableList.name: prop_state_values
TunableList.description: Tunable mapping from a prop actor name to a list of state values to set. If conflicting data is tuned both here and in the "props" field, the data inside "props" will override the data tuned here.

TunableList.name: value
TunableList.description: A list of state values that will be set on the specified actor.

Tunable.description: A new state value to apply to prop_actor.

TunableList.name: props
TunableList.description: The props overrides.

TunableVariant.name: alternative_prop_definitions
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows tuning other ways to override the prop. If none of these ways work, the tuned Definition will be used as a fallback.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Other ways to get a definition ID to override the prop.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Tuple to hold the favorite tag to search for and the actor ASM name.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite.
If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override.
If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override.
If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

Tunable.name: definition
Tunable.description: The object to create to replace the prop

Tunable.name: from_actor
Tunable.description: The actor name inside the asm to copy the state over.

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description:
With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time.
No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop).
Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order.
e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared.
When the last "Leash" interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

TunableTuple.name: parameter

TunableVariant.name: max_water_depth
TunableVariant.description: (float) If provided, each vertex of the test polygon along with its centroid will be tested to determine whether the ocean water at the test location is at most this deep. Values <= 0 indicate placement in ocean is invalid.

Tunable.name: enabled

TunableVariant.name: min_water_depth

Tunable.name: enabled

TunableTuple.name: water_depth_interval

TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

TunableList.name: prop_state_values
TunableList.description: Tunable mapping from a prop actor name to a list of state values to set. If conflicting data is tuned both here and in the "props" field, the data inside "props" will override the data tuned here.

TunableList.name: value
TunableList.description: A list of state values that will be set on the specified actor.

Tunable.description: A new state value to apply to prop_actor.

TunableList.name: props
TunableList.description: The props overrides.

TunableVariant.name: alternative_prop_definitions
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows tuning other ways to override the prop. If none of these ways work, the tuned Definition will be used as a fallback.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Other ways to get a definition ID to override the prop.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Tuple to hold the favorite tag to search for and the actor ASM name.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite.
If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override.
If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override.
If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

Tunable.name: definition
Tunable.description: The object to create to replace the prop

Tunable.name: from_actor
Tunable.description: The actor name inside the asm to copy the state over.

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description:
With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time.
No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop).
Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order.
e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared.
When the last "Leash" interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

TunableTuple.name: actor
TunableTuple.description: This key is an actor. The object is resolved given the actor name for the specified ASM.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: The actor that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: literal
TunableTuple.description: This key is a literal string. It's independent of anything that might be set on the ASM.

Tunable.name: literal
Tunable.description: The literal string that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: parameter
TunableTuple.description: They key is a parameter. Its value is resolved given the parameter name for the specified ASM.

TunableVariant.name: actor_name
TunableVariant.description: The actor for which this parameter's value is to be used.

Tunable.name: Specified
Tunable.description: The actor name.

Tunable.name: parameter_name
Tunable.description: The parameter whose value is to be used.

TunableTuple.description: Tuning for special case prop overrides.

TunableVariant.name: set_baby_cloth_from_actor
TunableVariant.description: If tuned, will set the baby's outfit based on a baby that is already an actor in the asm.

TunableList.name: states_to_override
TunableList.description: A list of states that will be transferred from the specified actor to the overridden prop.

Tunable.description: The state to apply on the props from the actor listed above.

TunableVariant.name: reactionlet
TunableVariant.description: Reactionlets are short, one-shot animations that are triggered via x-event. X-events are markers in clips that can trigger an in-game effect that is timed perfectly with the clip. Ex: This is how we trigger laughter at the exact moment of the punchline of a Joke It is EXTREMELY important that only content authored and configured by animators to be used as a Reactionlet gets hooked up as Reactionlet content. If this rule is violated, crazy things will happen including the client and server losing time sync.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Reactionlets are short, one-shot animations that are triggered via x-event. X-events are markers in clips that can trigger an in-game effect that is timed perfectly with the clip. Ex: This is how we trigger laughter at the exact moment of the punchline of a Joke It is EXTREMELY important that only content authored and configured by animators to be used as a Reactionlet gets hooked up as Reactionlet content. If this rule is violated, crazy things will happen including the client and server losing time sync.

TunableTuple.name: participant
TunableTuple.description: There is an arbitrary number of possible animation selectors, based on participation in group.

TunableList.name: groups
TunableList.description: A list of difficulty to animation mappings.

TunableTuple.name: overrides
TunableTuple.description: The overrides for interaction to replace the tunings on the animation elements

Tunable.name: animation_context
Tunable.description: Animation Context - If checked, this animation will get a fresh animation context instead of reusing the animation context of its Interaction. Normally, animation contexts are shared across an entire Super Interaction. This allows mixers to use a fresh animation context. Ex: If a mixer creates a prop, using a fresh animation context will cause that prop to be destroyed when the mixer finishes, whereas re-using an existing animation context will cause the prop to stick around until the mixer's SI is done.

TunableVariant.name: balloons
TunableVariant.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.name: enabled
TunableList.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableTuple.name: replacement_effect
TunableTuple.description: Override data for the specified effect actor.

TunableVariant.name: callback_event_id
TunableVariant.description:
Specifies a callback xevt id we want the vfx to trigger when it fulfills a contracted duty.
For example, it can call this xevt on point-to-point vfx if the effect reaches the target event.

TunableVariant.name: effect
TunableVariant.description: Override the actual effect that is meant to be played. It can be left None to stop the effect from playing

TunableVariant.name: effect_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the effect joint of the VFX. Use this specify a different joint name to attach the effect to.

TunableVariant.name: mirrored_effect
TunableVariant.description: If enabled and the is_mirrored parameter comes through as True, we will play this effect instead of the tuned override. NOTE: if you tune this, the non-mirrored version must also be tuned in the regular effect override for it to play. For example, the Bubble Bottle needs to play mirrored effects for left handed Sims, but if we don't override the effect and still want to play a mirrored version, we need to specify the original effect so we don't play nothing.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The name of the mirrored effect.

TunableVariant.name: target_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint of the VFX. This is used in case of attractors where we want the effect to target a different place per object on the same animation

TunableVariant.name: target_joint_offset
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint offset of the VFX. This is used in case of point to point VFX where we want the effect to reach a destination offset from the target joint.

TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

TunableList.name: prop_state_values
TunableList.description: Tunable mapping from a prop actor name to a list of state values to set. If conflicting data is tuned both here and in the "props" field, the data inside "props" will override the data tuned here.

TunableList.name: value
TunableList.description: A list of state values that will be set on the specified actor.

Tunable.description: A new state value to apply to prop_actor.

TunableList.name: props
TunableList.description: The props overrides.

TunableVariant.name: alternative_prop_definitions
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows tuning other ways to override the prop. If none of these ways work, the tuned Definition will be used as a fallback.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Other ways to get a definition ID to override the prop.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

TunableTuple.name: enabled

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite.
If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override.
If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override.
If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

Tunable.name: definition
Tunable.description: The object to create to replace the prop

Tunable.name: from_actor
Tunable.description: The actor name inside the asm to copy the state over.

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description:
With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time.
No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop).
Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order.
e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared.
When the last "Leash" interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

Tunable.description: The actor that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: parameter

TunableVariant.name: callback_event_id
TunableVariant.description:
Specifies a callback xevt id we want the vfx to trigger when it fulfills a contracted duty.
For example, it can call this xevt on point-to-point vfx if the effect reaches the target event.

TunableVariant.name: effect
TunableVariant.description: Override the actual effect that is meant to be played. It can be left None to stop the effect from playing

TunableVariant.name: effect_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the effect joint of the VFX. Use this specify a different joint name to attach the effect to.

TunableVariant.name: mirrored_effect
TunableVariant.description: If enabled and the is_mirrored parameter comes through as True, we will play this effect instead of the tuned override. NOTE: if you tune this, the non-mirrored version must also be tuned in the regular effect override for it to play. For example, the Bubble Bottle needs to play mirrored effects for left handed Sims, but if we don't override the effect and still want to play a mirrored version, we need to specify the original effect so we don't play nothing.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The name of the mirrored effect.

TunableVariant.name: target_joint

TunableVariant.name: target_joint_offset
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint offset of the VFX. This is used in case of point to point VFX where we want the effect to reach a destination offset from the target joint.

Tunable.name: animation_context
Tunable.description: Animation Context - If checked, this animation will get a fresh animation context instead of reusing the animation context of its Interaction. Normally, animation contexts are shared across an entire Super Interaction. This allows mixers to use a fresh animation context. Ex: If a mixer creates a prop, using a fresh animation context will cause that prop to be destroyed when the mixer finishes, whereas re-using an existing animation context will cause the prop to stick around until the mixer's SI is done.

TunableVariant.name: balloons
TunableVariant.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableList.description: Balloons lets you add thought and talk balloons to animations. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

TunableVariant.name: reactionlet
TunableVariant.description: Reactionlets are short, one-shot animations that are triggered via x-event. X-events are markers in clips that can trigger an in-game effect that is timed perfectly with the clip. Ex: This is how we trigger laughter at the exact moment of the punchline of a Joke It is EXTREMELY important that only content authored and configured by animators to be used as a Reactionlet gets hooked up as Reactionlet content. If this rule is violated, crazy things will happen including the client and server losing time sync.

This is a great way to put extra flavor into animations and helps us stretch our content by creating combinations. Balloon Animation Target is the participant who should display the balloon. Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

Balloon Choices is a reference to the balloon to display, which is its own tunable type. Balloon Delay (and Random Offset) is how long, in real seconds, to delay this balloon after the animation starts. Note: for looping animations, the balloon will always play immediately due to a code limitation. Balloon Target is for showing a balloon of a Sim or Object. Set this to the participant type to show. This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

Tunable.name: balloon_delay_random_offset
Tunable.description: The amount of randomization that is added to balloon requests. Will always offset the delay time later, and requires the delay time to be set to a number. A value of 0 has no randomization.

TunableList.name: manifests
TunableList.description: Manifests is a complex and seldom used override that lets you change entries in the posture manifest from the ASM. You can see how the fields, Actor, Family, Level, Specific, Left, Right, and Surface, match the manifest entries in the ASM.

TunableList.name: params
TunableList.description: This tuning is used for overriding parameters on the ASM to specific values. These will take precedence over those same settings coming from runtime so be careful! You can enter a number of overrides as key/value pairs: Name is the name of the parameter as it appears in the ASM. Value is the value to set on the ASM. Make sure to get the type right. Parameters are either booleans, enums, or strings. Ex: The most common usage of this field is when tuning the custom parameters on specific objects, such as the objectName parameter.

TunableList.name: prop_state_values
TunableList.description: Tunable mapping from a prop actor name to a list of state values to set. If conflicting data is tuned both here and in the "props" field, the data inside "props" will override the data tuned here.

TunableList.name: value
TunableList.description: A list of state values that will be set on the specified actor.

Tunable.description: A new state value to apply to prop_actor.

TunableList.name: props
TunableList.description: The props overrides.

TunableVariant.name: alternative_prop_definitions
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows tuning other ways to override the prop. If none of these ways work, the tuned Definition will be used as a fallback.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Other ways to get a definition ID to override the prop.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_by_definition
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, looks for a favorite object not necessarily in the Sim's inventory.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Tuple to hold the favorite tag to search for and the actor ASM name.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type it will be set as the favorite.
If it does not, the tuned definition will be set instead.

TunableVariant.name: favorite_object_in_inventory
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, allows looking for and using a favorite object in the Sim's inventory.

Tunable.name: actor_asm_name
Tunable.description: The name of the actor in the ASM. This is usually 'x' or 'y'.

TunableEnum.name: favorite_tag
TunableEnum.description:
If the Sim has a favorite object of this type currently in their inventory, it will be used as the prop override.
If the Sim doesn't have a favorite of this type, or their favorite is not currently in their inventory, a random object found in their inventory with this tag will be used as the prop override.
If there aren't any objects with this tag in the Sim's inventory then the prop override will fall back to the tuned Definition.

TdescFragTag.name: random_choice_tests
TdescFragTag.description: Objects with the favorite tag to be randomly chosen from inventory should pass these tests first.

Tunable.name: definition
Tunable.description: The object to create to replace the prop

Tunable.name: from_actor
Tunable.description: The actor name inside the asm to copy the state over.

TunableVariant.name: set_as_actor
TunableVariant.description: If enabled the prop defined by override will be set as an actor of the ASM. This is used in cases like setting the chopsticks prop on the eat ASM. In this ASM the chopsticks are set as an Object actor so they can animate. Currently we do not support props playing their own animations.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: Actor name that will be used on the ASM for the prop animation.

TunableVariant.name: sharing
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, this prop may be shared across ASMs.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description:
With this override tuned, different ASMs can share the same prop. A key can be built out of several elements that allow multiple shares to be active at the same time.
No new prop is created if a share is active. Instead, an existing prop is returned and all events operate on that prop (be careful if the animation has visibility events that hide the prop).
Conversely, no prop is destroyed until all shares are deactivated. This allows the sharing to be interleaved, such two shares don't necessarily have to relinquish their claim on the prop in inverse order.
e.g.: * Sims can leash multiple dogs at the same time (using either hand). For the same hand, there are multiple leashes but only one leash holder prop, which needs to be shared.
When the last "Leash" interaction for that hand ends, the leash holder needs to be destroyed.

TunableList.name: key
TunableList.description: A list of elements that form the key for this share. For keys that are identical, props are shared.

TunableTuple.name: actor
TunableTuple.description: This key is an actor. The object is resolved given the actor name for the specified ASM.

Tunable.name: actor_name
Tunable.description: The actor that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: literal
TunableTuple.description: This key is a literal string. It's independent of anything that might be set on the ASM.

Tunable.name: literal
Tunable.description: The literal string that is to be used as a key.

TunableTuple.name: parameter
TunableTuple.description: They key is a parameter. Its value is resolved given the parameter name for the specified ASM.

TunableVariant.name: actor_name
TunableVariant.description: The actor for which this parameter's value is to be used.

Tunable.name: Specified
Tunable.description: The actor name.

Tunable.name: parameter_name
Tunable.description: The parameter whose value is to be used.

TunableTuple.name: special_cases
TunableTuple.description: Tuning for special case prop overrides.

TunableVariant.name: set_baby_cloth_from_actor
TunableVariant.description: If tuned, will set the baby's outfit based on a baby that is already an actor in the asm.

TunableList.name: states_to_override
TunableList.description: A list of states that will be transferred from the specified actor to the overridden prop.

Tunable.description: The state to apply on the props from the actor listed above.

TunableList.name: required_slots
TunableList.description: Required slot overrides

TunableList.name: sounds
TunableList.description: The sound overrides.

TunableVariant.name: replacement_sound
TunableVariant.description: The sound to play.

Tunable.name: play_sound
Tunable.description: The sound to play.

TunableList.name: vfx
TunableList.description: VFX overrides for this animation. The key is the effect's actor name. Please note, this is not the name of the vfx that would normally play. This is the name of the actor in the ASM that is associated to a specific effect.

TunableTuple.name: replacement_effect
TunableTuple.description: Override data for the specified effect actor.

TunableVariant.name: callback_event_id
TunableVariant.description:
Specifies a callback xevt id we want the vfx to trigger when it fulfills a contracted duty.
For example, it can call this xevt on point-to-point vfx if the effect reaches the target event.

TunableVariant.name: effect
TunableVariant.description: Override the actual effect that is meant to be played. It can be left None to stop the effect from playing

TunableVariant.name: effect_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the effect joint of the VFX. Use this specify a different joint name to attach the effect to.

TunableVariant.name: mirrored_effect
TunableVariant.description: If enabled and the is_mirrored parameter comes through as True, we will play this effect instead of the tuned override. NOTE: if you tune this, the non-mirrored version must also be tuned in the regular effect override for it to play. For example, the Bubble Bottle needs to play mirrored effects for left handed Sims, but if we don't override the effect and still want to play a mirrored version, we need to specify the original effect so we don't play nothing.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The name of the mirrored effect.

TunableVariant.name: target_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint of the VFX. This is used in case of attractors where we want the effect to target a different place per object on the same animation

TunableVariant.name: target_joint_offset
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint offset of the VFX. This is used in case of point to point VFX where we want the effect to reach a destination offset from the target joint.

TunableTuple.name: fixed
TunableTuple.description: A fixed offset.

Tunable.name: upper_bound

Tunable.name: offset
Tunable.description: An offset (rotation) in degrees, affecting where the start of the angle is. This has no effect if angle is 360 degrees.

TunableTuple.name: overrides

Tunable.name: animation_context
Tunable.description: Animation Context - If checked, this animation will get a fresh animation context instead of reusing the animation context of its Interaction. Normally, animation contexts are shared across an entire Super Interaction. This allows mixers to use a fresh animation context. Ex: If a mixer creates a prop, using a fresh animation context will cause that prop to be destroyed when the mixer finishes, whereas re-using an existing animation context will cause the prop to stick around until the mixer's SI is done.

This setting overrides Balloon Choices.

Tunable.name: upper_bound
Tunable.description: The upper bound of the interval.

Tunable.name: offset
Tunable.description: An offset (rotation) in degrees, affecting where the start of the angle is. This has no effect if angle is 360 degrees.

TunableList.name: required_slots
TunableList.description: Required slot overrides

TunableList.name: sounds
TunableList.description: The sound overrides.

TunableVariant.name: replacement_sound
TunableVariant.description: The sound to play.

Tunable.name: play_sound
Tunable.description: The sound to play.

TunableList.name: vfx
TunableList.description: VFX overrides for this animation. The key is the effect's actor name. Please note, this is not the name of the vfx that would normally play. This is the name of the actor in the ASM that is associated to a specific effect.

TunableTuple.name: replacement_effect
TunableTuple.description: Override data for the specified effect actor.

TunableVariant.name: callback_event_id
TunableVariant.description:
Specifies a callback xevt id we want the vfx to trigger when it fulfills a contracted duty.
For example, it can call this xevt on point-to-point vfx if the effect reaches the target event.

TunableVariant.name: effect
TunableVariant.description: Override the actual effect that is meant to be played. It can be left None to stop the effect from playing

TunableVariant.name: effect_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the effect joint of the VFX. Use this specify a different joint name to attach the effect to.

TunableVariant.name: mirrored_effect
TunableVariant.description: If enabled and the is_mirrored parameter comes through as True, we will play this effect instead of the tuned override. NOTE: if you tune this, the non-mirrored version must also be tuned in the regular effect override for it to play. For example, the Bubble Bottle needs to play mirrored effects for left handed Sims, but if we don't override the effect and still want to play a mirrored version, we need to specify the original effect so we don't play nothing.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The name of the mirrored effect.

TunableVariant.name: target_joint
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint of the VFX. This is used in case of attractors where we want the effect to target a different place per object on the same animation

TunableVariant.name: target_joint_offset
TunableVariant.description: Overrides the target joint offset of the VFX. This is used in case of point to point VFX where we want the effect to reach a destination offset from the target joint.

TunableTuple.name: fixed
TunableTuple.description: A fixed offset.

Tunable.name: x
Tunable.description: x component

Tunable.name: y
Tunable.description: y component

Tunable.name: z
Tunable.description: z component

TunableTuple.name: random_in_circle
TunableTuple.description: Specify a random offset within given full/partial circle/donut.

Tunable.name: angle
Tunable.description: The slice of the donut/circle in degrees.

TunableVariant.name: axis
TunableVariant.description: Around which axis the position will be located.

TunableTuple.name: distance
TunableTuple.description: The distance range relative to origin point that the generated point should be in.

Tunable.name: lower_bound
Tunable.description: The lower bound of the interval.

Tunable.name: upper_bound
Tunable.description: The upper bound of the interval.

Tunable.name: offset
Tunable.description: An offset (rotation) in degrees, affecting where the start of the angle is. This has no effect if angle is 360 degrees.

Tunable.name: _jig_name
Tunable.description: The actor name for the jig created by this posture, if a jig is tuned.

Tunable.name: _set_locomotion_surface
Tunable.description:
If checked, then the Sim's locomotion surface is set to the target of this posture, if it exists.
The locomotion surface affects the sound of the Sim's footsteps when locomoting. Generally, this should be unset, since most Sims don't route on objects as part of postures. For the cases where they do, however, we need to ensure the sound is properly overridden.
e.g. The "Sit" posture for Cats includes sitting on objects. Some of those transitions involve Cats walking across the sofa. We need to ensure that the sound of the footsteps matches the fabric, instead of the floor/ground.

Tunable.name: _state_name
Tunable.description: The main state name for the looping posture pose in the ASM. All postures should have two public states, not including entry and exit. This should be the second of the two states.

Tunable.name: _target_name
Tunable.description: The actor name for the target object of this posture. Leave empty for postures with no target. In the case of a posture that targets an object, it should be the name of the object actor in this posture's ASM.

Tunable.name: _apply_target_to_interaction_asms
Tunable.description:
When checked, we apply the targets in the posture ASM to other ASMs that support the posture. This is important for postures like Sit, because if you're doing a seated chat, the social needs to have the sitTemplate because it's referenced in the animations.
For a posture like Swim, the sit template is only used in the portal animation, so other ASMs don't need the virtual actors.

TunableTuple.description: A list of postures that this posture supports entrance from and exit to.

TunableVariant.name: entry
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, an edge is generated from the supported posture to this posture.

TunableTuple.name: custom_cost
TunableTuple.description: The cost to transition between the two postures is defined by this custom number, as opposed to using the generic cost.

Tunable.name: cost
Tunable.description: The cost to transition between the two postures.

TunableTuple.name: default_cost
TunableTuple.description: The cost to transition between the two postures is defined by the global posture transition cost.

TunableTuple.name: per_species_cost
TunableTuple.description: The cost to transition between the two postures is tuned on a per-species level.

Tunable.name: default_cost
Tunable.description: The cost to transition between the two postures for a species without any specific tuning.

TunableList.name: species_cost
TunableList.description: For each species, define the cost to transition between the two postures.

TunableEnum.name: key
TunableEnum.description: The species this cost applies to.

Tunable.name: value
Tunable.description: For this species, the cost to transition between the two postures.

TunableList.name: validators
TunableList.description:
Define under what circumstances this transition is valid. There are performance implications of adding tested edges to the posture graph.
In general, this should be handled by testing posture- providing interactions altogether. This should really only be used to restrict the ability to go from a specific posture to another specific posture under certain circumstances.
e.g. Prevent Squeamish Sims from sitting on dirty toilets. * Do not use this tuning. Instead, test out the interaction directly.
e.g. Prevent Toddlers with low motor skill from entering the High Chair posture from stand. However, allow them to be placed on the High Chair from carry. * Use this tuning.

TunableTuple.name: test
TunableTuple.description:
The ability to transition from one posture to another is gated by a tunable test.
These tests should be kept light-weight, to avoid performance degradation during transition sequence generation.

Tunable.name: test_set
Tunable.description:
This test set is provided with a DoubleSimResolver. The Actor participant is the transitioning Sim. The Object/TargetSim participant is the posture container we're testing against.
Should the test fail, the posture transition is deemed invalid and is discarded.

TunableVariant.name: exit
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, an edge is generated from this posture to the supported posture.

TunableTuple.description: The cost to transition between the two postures is defined by this custom number, as opposed to using the generic cost.

Tunable.name: posture_type
Tunable.description: A supported posture.

Tunable.name: _supports_carry
Tunable.description: Whether or not there should be a carry version of this posture in the posture graph.

Tunable.name: additional_interaction_jig_fgl_distance
Tunable.description: An additional distance (in meters) in front of the Sim to start searching when using FGL to place a Jig to run an interaction.

Tunable.name: additional_put_down_distance
Tunable.description:
An additional distance in front of the Sim to start searching for valid put down locations when in this posture.
This tunable is only respected for the Sim's body posture.

Tunable.name: allow_affinity
Tunable.description:
If True, Sims will prefer to use this posture if someone they're interacting with is using the posture.
e.g.: If you chat with a sitting Sim, you will prefer to sit with them and chat.

Tunable.name: allow_social_adjustment
Tunable.description:
If enabled, Sims in this posture will still be considered for social adjustment. If disabled, Sims in this posture will not be considered for social adjustment.
e.g.: When a Sim is sitting in the hospital exam bed, we never want them to stand up out of it due to social adjustment, because it doesn't make sense in context. They should stay in the bed when Sims chat with them.

TunableVariant.name: appearance_modifier
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, we will apply an appearance modifier on the entry and exit animations for this posture.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Appearance Modifier and xevents for entry and exit, which default to the posture's xevents.

Tunable.name: entry_xevt
Tunable.description: The xevent id to apply the appearance modifier.

Tunable.name: exit_xevt
Tunable.description: The xevent id to remove the appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.name: modifier
TunableTuple.description: A tunable modifier to a Sim's appearance that lasts for the duration of the buff.

TunableList.name: additional_flags
TunableList.description: Additional flags that will be sent as part of this outfit override. Note, ignore_bathing is only valid if apply_to_all_outfits is also checked.

TunableList.name: appearance_modifiers
TunableList.description: The specific appearance modifiers to use for this buff.
A tunable list of weighted modifiers. When applying modifiers one of the modifiers in this list will be applied. The weight will be used to run a weighted random selection.

TunableTuple.description: A Modifier to apply and weight for the weighted random selection.

TunableTuple.name: generate_outfit
TunableTuple.description:
Generates an outfit using the Sim's current outfits to pull from.
Note: Be sure to supply Body Type Flags either in the chance overrides or match not found policy. Otherwise, we use CLOTHING ALL. If you don't specify which flags you intend to use, it's possible the generator may have undefined behavior. Use flags if you intend on changing known cas part types on the Sim.

Tunable.name: _is_combinable_with_same_type
Tunable.description: True if this modifier type is able to be combined with another of its type. If True, and two modifiers conflict, then the tuned priority will be used to resolve the conflict. If False, only a single modifier of this type with the highest priority will be shown.

TunableVariant.name: appearance_modifier_tag
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, a tag used to reference this appearance modifier.

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: Tag associated with this appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.name: outfit_generator
TunableTuple.description: Inputs to generate the type of outfit we want.

TunableList.name: body_type_chance_overrides
TunableList.description:
Define body type chance overrides for the generate outfit. For example, if BODYTYPE_HAT is mapped to 100%, then the outfit is guaranteed to have a hat if any hat matches the specified tags.
If used in an appearance modifier, these body types will contribute to the flags that determine which body types can be generated, regardless of their percent chance.

Tunable.name: value
Tunable.description: The chance that a part is applied to the corresponding body type.

TunableList.name: body_type_match_not_found_policy
TunableList.display: Body Type Match Not Found Policy
TunableList.description:
The policy we should take for a body type that we fail to find a match for. Primary example is to use MATCH_NOT_FOUND_KEEP_EXISTING for generating a tshirt and making sure a sim wearing full body has a lower body cas part.
If used in an appearance modifier, these body types will contribute to the flags that determine which body types can be generated.

TunableList.name: filter_flag
TunableList.description: Define how to handle part randomization for the generated outfit.

TunableList.name: tags
TunableList.description: The set of tags used to generate the outfit. Parts must match the specified tag in order to be valid for the generated outfit.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_override
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, we will generate the outfit on the tuned outfit category and index. Otherwise, we use the Sim's current outfit in the generator.

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: The outfit category we want to generate the outfit on.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_type_compatibility
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, will verify when switching outfits if the new outfit is compatible with this appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.description: The outfit category must match the whitelist and blacklist to be applied.

TunableTuple.name: threshold
TunableTuple.description: When testing a collection of items, the number of items in that collection that are in the blacklist must pass this threshold test for the blacklist to disallow them all.

TunableEnum.name: comparison

TunableEnum.description: The outfit category want to test against the apperance modifier.

TunableList.name: replace_part_map
TunableList.description: The CAS part (value) that will replace another CAS part (key) if sim has that equipped. It currently only replaces the first one which it finds. Nothing will be replaced if the sim doesn't have any of the key CAS parts set.

Tunable.name: key
Tunable.description: CAS part to look up.

Tunable.name: value
Tunable.description: If key CAS part is set, replace it with this CAS part.

Tunable.name: update_genetics
Tunable.description: Whether or not to update the genetics of the sim with this modification to make it a permanent modification. NOTE: DO NOT tune permanent with temporary modifications on the same appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.name: set_cas_part
TunableTuple.description: Sets the tuned CAS part. Also has an option to toggle the existence of the tuned CAS part.

Tunable.name: _is_combinable_with_same_type
Tunable.description: True if this modifier type is able to be combined with another of its type. If True, and two modifiers conflict, then the tuned priority will be used to resolve the conflict. If False, only a single modifier of this type with the highest priority will be shown.

TunableVariant.name: appearance_modifier_tag
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, a tag used to reference this appearance modifier.

TunableEnum.name: enabled
TunableEnum.description: Tag associated with this appearance modifier.

Tunable.name: cas_part
Tunable.description: The CAS part that will be modified.

Tunable.name: expect_invalid_parts
Tunable.description: Whether or not parts that are invalid for a sim should log an error. If we are expecting invalid parts, (say, buff gives one part that applies to adults and a different part for children,) then we should set this to True so that it doesn't throw the error when it tries to apply the adult part on the child and vice versa.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_type_compatibility
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, will verify when switching outfits if the new outfit is compatible with this appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: The outfit category must match the whitelist and blacklist to be applied.

TunableVariant.name: blacklist
TunableVariant.description: When an item is tested against this white/black list, it is only allowed if it is not in the blacklist. If no blacklist is specified, no items are disallowed.

TunableTuple.name: specify
TunableTuple.description: A tunable blacklist.

TunableList.name: blacklist
TunableList.description: Blacklisted items.

TunableEnum.description: The outfit category want to test against the apperance modifier.

TunableVariant.name: threshold
TunableVariant.description: Tunable option for how many items must be in the blacklist for the blacklist to fail when testing a collection of items. By default, only one object needs to be in the list.

TunableTuple.name: threshold
TunableTuple.description: When testing a collection of items, the number of items in that collection that are in the blacklist must pass this threshold test for the blacklist to disallow them all.

TunableEnum.name: comparison
TunableEnum.description: The comparison to perform against the value.

TunableVariant.name: whitelist
TunableVariant.description: When an item is tested against this white/black list, it is only allowed if it is in the whitelist. If no whitelist is specified, all items are allowed.

TunableTuple.name: specify
TunableTuple.description: A tunable whitelist.

TunableVariant.name: threshold
TunableVariant.description: Tunable option for how many items must be in the whitelist for the whitelist to pass when testing a collection of items. By default, only one object needs to be in the list.

TunableTuple.name: threshold
TunableTuple.description: When testing a collection of items, the number of items in that collection that are in the whitelist must pass this threshold test for the whitelist to allow them all.

TunableEnum.name: comparison
TunableEnum.description: The comparison to perform against the value.

TunableList.name: whitelist
TunableList.description: Whitelisted items.

TunableEnum.description: The outfit category want to test against the apperance modifier.

Tunable.name: remove_conflicting
Tunable.description:
If checked, conflicting parts are removed from the outfit. For instance, a full body outfit might be removed if a part would conflict with it.
e.g. The Cone of Shame removes conflicting full-body pet outfits.

Tunable.name: replace_with_random
Tunable.description: Whether or not to replace the tuned cas part with a random variant.

Tunable.name: should_toggle
Tunable.description: Whether or not to toggle this part. e.g. if it exists, remove it, if it doesn't exist, add it. If set to false, the part will be added if it doesn't exist, but not removed if it does exist.

Tunable.name: update_genetics
Tunable.description: Whether or not to update the genetics of the sim with this modification to make it a permanent modification. NOTE: DO NOT tune permanent with temporary modifications on the same appearance modifier.

TunableTuple.name: weight
TunableTuple.description: A weight with testable multipliers that is used to determine how likely this entry is to be picked when selecting randomly.

Tunable.name: base_value
Tunable.description: The basic value to return if no modifications are applied.

TunableList.name: multipliers
TunableList.description: A list of multipliers to apply to base_value.

Tunable.name: multiplier
Tunable.description: The multiplier to apply to base_value if the associated tests pass.

TdescFragTag.name: tests
TdescFragTag.description: A series of tests that must pass in order for multiplier to be applied.

Tunable.name: apply_to_all_outfits
Tunable.description: If checked, the appearance modifiers will be applied to all outfits, otherwise they will only be applied to the current outfit.

TunableEnum.name: priority
TunableEnum.description: The priority of the appearance request. Higher priority will take precedence over lower priority. Equal priority will favor recent requests.

Tunable.name: consider_constrained_for_on_surface_checks
Tunable.display: Consider Constrained For On Surface Checks
Tunable.description: If True, this object will be considered on a surface even if it doesn't meet the normal geometric requirements. This is already the case for constrained postures but is not for unconstrained postures like stand. Please discuss this option with a GPE before using it.

Tunable.name: consider_posture_for_family_constraints
Tunable.description:
If checked, this posture will be always be a possible constraint when running an interaction which lists this posture's posture family in its constraint. If not checked, this posture will only be used in cases where it is 'specifically' in the constraint (either through tuning or a specific animation posture constraint) or cases where it results from an intersection of constraints.
For example, if I want a sim to do everything they can do in the sit posture in this posture and this posture is sit posture family, then I would check this box. This would be the case in a posture like rocking chair sit, where I want sims who use an object to automatically decide to rock while they perform their SI.
If instead I was adding a 'sit while fidgeting' posture that I want to be compatible with other sit interactions but which I only want to run if the sim runs a fidget interaction, I would not check this box. Checking this box would mean that a sim performing another task like reading a book might choose to enter the fidget posture to do it.

Tunable.name: cost
Tunable.description: ( >= 0 ) The distance a Sim is willing to pay to avoid using this posture (higher number discourage using the posture).

TunableList.name: default_animation_params
TunableList.description:
A list of param name, param value tuples will be used as the default for this posture. Should generally only be used if posture has different get ins, and the object name method (used in posture_sit) would require a significant amount of retuning, or would simply be impossible because the posture needs to also support @none.
example: posture_kneel (needs to support @none)

TunableVariant.name: global_validator
TunableVariant.description:
If enabled, specify a test that validates whether or not this posture is available for a given Sim and a target. Posture transition generation should be efficient, so this should only be reserved for postures whose availability is not strictly tied to a single interaction (e.g. carry).
e.g.: the "Carry Sim" posture can be transitioned in and out of as part of a transition sequence that requires, say, a toddler to sit on a sofa. We don't want to have adult Sims think they can be carried to transition to the same posture. So the "Carry Sim" posture globally validates that the Sim is a toddler and the target a TYAE Sim.
e.g.: Sims are supposed to be able to sit while reading. However, Sims are unable to sit on charred objects. If the object is charred, the posture providing interaction testing out is enough information for the transition sequence not to consider sitting a valid posture.

TunableTuple.name: test
TunableTuple.description:
The ability to transition from one posture to another is gated by a tunable test.
These tests should be kept light-weight, to avoid performance degradation during transition sequence generation.

Tunable.name: test_set
Tunable.description:
This test set is provided with a DoubleSimResolver. The Actor participant is the transitioning Sim. The Object/TargetSim participant is the posture container we're testing against.
Should the test fail, the posture transition is deemed invalid and is discarded.

Tunable.name: holster_for_entries_and_exits
Tunable.description: If enabled, the Sim will holster all carried objects before entering and exiting this posture.

TunableVariant.name: jig
TunableVariant.description: An optional jig to place while the Sim is in this posture.

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The jig to place while the Sim is in this posture.

TunableList.name: loot_actions_on_exit
TunableList.description:
List of loot actions to apply when exiting the posture.
Caution: This should only be used if we need the loot to apply after the exit transition has been planned by the Sim. eg. Removing a buff that is used in a validator to determine the correct posture to exit to.
Please talk to your GPE if you are adding loot actions here.

Tunable.name: mutex_entry_exit_animations
Tunable.description: Mutex the entrance / exit animations into / out of this posture. This is useful for preventing sims from clipping through each other while entering / exiting multi-reserve postures on the same part.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_change
TunableVariant.description: Define what outfits the Sim is supposed to wear when entering or exiting this posture.

TunableTuple.name: for_new
TunableTuple.description: Define an outfit change that generates a new outfit and then applies it to the Sim.

TunableTuple.name: outfit_change_behavior
TunableTuple.description: Generate a new outfit in the specified category.

TunableEnum.name: outfit_category
TunableEnum.description: The outfit category for which we're creating a new outfit.

TunableTuple.name: for_reason
TunableTuple.description: Define individual outfit changes at each of the transition points.

TunableVariant.name: on_entry
TunableVariant.description: When enabled, define the change reason to apply on posture entry.

TunableVariant.name: on_exit
TunableVariant.description: When enabled, define the change reason to apply on posture exit.

TunableTuple.name: for_tags
TunableTuple.description: Define an outfit to apply for the duration of the OutfitChange's owner generated from the specified tags.

TunableVariant.name: on_entry
TunableVariant.description: The tuning for how to handle the outfit change on entry of the new context.

TunableTuple.name: enabled
TunableTuple.description: Contains the tags used to tune the outfit and also a preference for whether or not to automatically switch out of the tags outfit when on exit.

Tunable.name: auto_undo_on_exit
Tunable.description:
If True then the Sim will switch out of the entry tag outfit on exit. If False then the Sim will stay in the tag outfit.
NOTE: This tuning conflicts with the On Exit tuning. If this is set to true and On Exit is enabled then an error should occur on load because you can't both switch out of the tag outfit and switch into a different tag outfit.

Tunable.name: do_spin
Tunable.description: If checked, the Sim will animate and perform a clothing change spin. If unchecked, the Sim will change outfits without animating.

TunableVariant.name: generator
TunableVariant.description: This may be tuned in place here using 'literal' or as a reference to a Outfit tuning snippet.

TunableTuple.name: literal
TunableTuple.description: A helper that generates outfits for a Sim. The tunables control aspects of randomization, such as tags, weights, overrides, etc...

TunableList.name: body_type_chance_overrides
TunableList.description:
Define body type chance overrides for the generate outfit. For example, if BODYTYPE_HAT is mapped to 100%, then the outfit is guaranteed to have a hat if any hat matches the specified tags.
If used in an appearance modifier, these body types will contribute to the flags that determine which body types can be generated, regardless of their percent chance.

Tunable.name: value
Tunable.description: The chance that a part is applied to the corresponding body type.

TunableList.name: body_type_match_not_found_policy
TunableList.display: Body Type Match Not Found Policy
TunableList.description:
The policy we should take for a body type that we fail to find a match for. Primary example is to use MATCH_NOT_FOUND_KEEP_EXISTING for generating a tshirt and making sure a sim wearing full body has a lower body cas part.
If used in an appearance modifier, these body types will contribute to the flags that determine which body types can be generated.

TunableList.name: filter_flag
TunableList.description: Define how to handle part randomization for the generated outfit.

TunableList.name: tags
TunableList.description: The set of tags used to generate the outfit. Parts must match the specified tag in order to be valid for the generated outfit.

Tunable.name: reference
Tunable.description: A reference to a Outfit tuning snippet.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_to_modify
TunableVariant.description: The outfit we want to generate over.

TunableTuple.name: current
TunableTuple.description: Outfit Variant to use a Sim's current outfit.

Tunable.name: restrict_to_regular
Tunable.description:
If checked, the Sim will switch out of any non-regular outfits (and into Everyday) before applying the modification.
If this is unchecked, the Sim will modify whatever outfit they are wearing, including, for example, career outfits. The modification is permanent.

TunableTuple.name: outfit_category
TunableTuple.description: OutfitVariant to use one of the Sim's outfit categories.

TunableEnum.name: outfit_category
TunableEnum.description: Outfit Category

TunableTuple.name: special
TunableTuple.description: Outfit Variant to use special outfits.

TunableEnum.name: special_outfit_index
TunableEnum.description:
The Special outfit index to use when creating the outfit using the provided flags. There are multiple Special outfits that are indexed by the entries in the SpecialOutfitIndex enum.
GPE NOTE: If you want to add a new index you will need to add a value to SpecialOutfitIndex as well as change the values in outfit_tuning.py and OutfitTypes.h to allow for more special outfits.

TunableVariant.name: on_exit
TunableVariant.description: The clothing change that happens on exit of the current context.

TunableList.name: enabled
TunableList.description: A list of (tests, clothing change) tuples. The first entry that passes all of its tests will be used while the other entries after that one will be ignored. So the order of the list is essentially priority.

TunableTuple.description: A tuple of clothing changes and tests for whether they should happen or not.

TunableVariant.name: generator
TunableVariant.description: This may be tuned in place here using 'literal' or as a reference to a Outfit tuning snippet.

TunableList.description: The set of tags used to generate the outfit. Parts must match the specified tag in order to be valid for the generated outfit.

Tunable.description: A reference to a Outfit tuning snippet.

TunableVariant.description: The outfit we want to generate over.

TunableTuple.description: Outfit Variant to use a Sim's current outfit.

TunableTuple.description: OutfitVariant to use one of the Sim's outfit categories.

TunableEnum.name: outfit_category
TunableEnum.description: Outfit Category

TdescFragTag.name: tests
TdescFragTag.description: Tests to run when deciding which clothing change entry to use. All of the tests must pass in order for the item to pass.

TunableTuple.name: from_participant
TunableTuple.description: Define an outfit change that takes the current outfit from the specified source and applies it to the Sim, in a specified way (such as a temporary application or a permanent addition).

TunableVariant.name: outfit_change_behavior
TunableVariant.description: Define how this outfit is to be applied to the Sim.

TunableTuple.name: addition
TunableTuple.description: The outfit on the source is copied and added to the Sim's outfits (matching the category on the source). The Sim is then switched to it.

TunableTuple.name: temporary
TunableTuple.description: The Sim is switched into the outfit from the participant temporarily. On exit, they are returned to the previous outfit.

TunableEnum.name: outfit_participant
TunableEnum.description: The Sim or object whose current outfit is going to be temporarily applied to the Sim being affected by this change.

TunableTuple.name: from_picker
TunableTuple.description: Define an outfit change by retrieving the picker selection for the interaction.

TunableVariant.name: timing
TunableVariant.description: Define when this outfit change happens.

TunableTuple.name: on_entry
TunableTuple.description: The outfit change happens on entry.

TunableTuple.name: on_exit
TunableTuple.description: The outfit change happens on exit.

TunableTuple.name: from_zone
TunableTuple.description:
The Sim is switched into the zone-specified outfit.
This tracked as a temporary outfit which does not persist.

Tunable.name: auto_undo_on_exit
Tunable.description:
If checked, the Sim will use the previous outfit as the on_exit outfit for this outfit change.
Has no effect for outfit changes that do not perform an on_exit change, such as on_route outfit changes.

TunableTuple.name: no_change
TunableTuple.description: Define no outfit change.

TunableVariant.name: outfit_exit_xevt
TunableVariant.description:
If enabled, the exit outfit change for this posture executes on an event. This is useful if the animation itself incorporates some sort of outfit switch.
If disabled, the outfit change normally occurs after the posture has exited, before the transition to the next posture (if supported).

Tunable.name: enabled
Tunable.description: The event to trigger the outfit change on.

TunableList.name: override_outfit_changes
TunableList.description: Define override outfits for entering this posture. The first override that passes its tests will be applied.

TunableTuple.description: Define an outfit change by retrieving the picker selection for the interaction.

TunableVariant.name: timing
TunableVariant.description: Define when this outfit change happens.

TunableTuple.name: on_entry
TunableTuple.description: The outfit change happens on entry.

TunableTuple.name: on_exit
TunableTuple.description: The outfit change happens on exit.

TunableTuple.name: from_zone
TunableTuple.description:
The Sim is switched into the zone-specified outfit.
This tracked as a temporary outfit which does not persist.

Tunable.name: auto_undo_on_exit
Tunable.description:
If checked, the Sim will use the previous outfit as the on_exit outfit for this outfit change.
Has no effect for outfit changes that do not perform an on_exit change, such as on_route outfit changes.

TunableTuple.name: no_change
TunableTuple.description: Define no outfit change.

TdescFragTag.name: tests
TdescFragTag.description: Tests to determine if this override should be applied.

Tunable.name: ownable
Tunable.description:
When checked, this posture is ownable by interactions.
e.g.: A posture like carry_nothing should not be ownable, because it will cause strange cancelations that don't make sense.

Tunable.name: prebuild_boundary_conditions
Tunable.description:
Whether or not to pre-load boundary conditions for this posture on startup.
This is a performance optimization that prevents spikes during gameplay when a posture is first used by ensuring that the posture's boundary conditions are built early on.
While this improves gameplay performance in game, note this also may increase initial tuning load time during unpacking of boundary conditions from the pre-built cache.
This is meant to be set to True for postures whose boundary condition generation is heavier than normal.
e.g. Sit, CarrySim, CarryObject, TakeBath, BedSleep

Tunable.name: rerequests_idles
Tunable.description:
If checked, this posture needs to re-request its idle in-between actions to ensure that there are no gaps in between interactions.
This should be unchecked for postures like those in the movingStand family like Swim for which interaction animations play on Normal Plus. These postures shouldn't re-request their idles because the idles on the Normal track will never be stopped.

TunableTuple.name: social_geometry
TunableTuple.description: The special geometry for socialization in this posture.

TunableTuple.name: focal_point
TunableTuple.description: Focal point when socializing in this posture, relative to Sim

Tunable.name: x
Tunable.description: x component

Tunable.name: y
Tunable.description: y component

Tunable.name: z
Tunable.description: z component

TunableList.name: social_space
TunableList.description:
The special geometry override for socialization in this posture. This defines where the Sim's attention is focused and informs the social positioning system where each Sim should stand to look most natural when interacting with this Sim.
e.g.: we override the social geometry for a Sim who is tending the bar to be a wider cone and be in front of the bar instead of embedded within the bar. This encourages Sims to stand on the customer- side of the bar to socialize with this Sim instead of coming around the back.

TunableEnum.description: The surface type this posture is on. e.g. stand is on the world surface and swim is on the pool surface

TunableVariant.name: switch_occult
TunableVariant.description: If enabled, switch the Sim into the specified occult type.
